Author: helpwitheating
Text: Don't exercise to change your body. That'll only make it an anxious endeavour for you.  Find an exercise you love and do it because you love it. Something where you think, "even if I knew this wouldn't change my body, I would do it."

Author: transedthrowaway
Text: As someone else who lives with chronic pain - listen to your body, and start with baby steps. I can't do a lot of super intense stuff because of my fibromyalgia, so I try to do 10,000 steps per day because I know I can USUALLY handle walking. But some days I can't even do that, and I certainly couldn't do that in the beginning!  When I was trying to go out and walk more, I started with 2500 steps per day and went up as my body became used to it. Same goes for the exercises I can do on good pain days - like pilates and weight lifting at home. I'd start with 3 minutes of pilates, and 2 sets of 10 reps for whatever weight training exercise I was doing that day. Again, starting small and gradually working your way up is the important thing.  Think of the type of exercise you want to do, and take a slow and patient approach to getting back into it.  And remember: if there are days when you can't do something because of your pain, that's okay! Don't beat yourself up. It's better to take a break or a day off when necessary to make sure you don't overexert yourself and cause more pain in the process. ðŸ’—
